text: hi I'm Melissa Clark from the dining
section and if you thought the best
pizza you can eat at home was the kind
you ordered in I'm here to prove
otherwise so to make homemade pizza the
first thing you need to do is get your
dough you can make it there are plenty
of recipes and cookbooks or you can find
it online personally I like to buy the
dough you can get it at the supermarket
in the freezer section or just go to
your local pizzeria and ask them if
they'll sell you a ball chances are they
will before you bake your pizza what you
want to do is heat up the surface that
you're going to be baking the pizza on I
have a piece of scone
but you can use it overturn baking sheet
and what you want to do is put it in the
oven and then crank the oven as high as
it'll go 500 is how high mine goes if
you're using a pizza stone it takes a
full hour for the pizza stone to heat up
a baking sheet takes about 30 minutes
while that's preheating you want to
stretch out your dough now this is the
part where you go to the pizzeria and
you see the guy rolling it over his head
and you think I can't do that you
actually don't have to do that there's
an easier way so you've got your dough
it should be cold you want to just flour
your surface use a lot of flour so it
doesn't stick get your dough nice and
Flowery now this is the cake you want to
move it around if you keep pressing it
in the same place you are going to glue
the dough into your counter and that is
bad so you want to keep it moving and
just press it out with your fingers you
want to press from the center because
the edges should be a little bit thicker
and then this is the fun part you want
to use the weight of the pizza dough to
thin it out so I'm just kind of moving
it around shaking a little bit almost
like driving a car another way you can
do it is to put your knuckles underneath
and stretch it like that personally I
like I like the shape method
shake shake what you don't want to do is
use a rolling pin that is just going to
flatten your dough right into the
counter you are not making pie you want
making pizza now I'm not going to try it
no pizza dough is pretty forgiving it's
not like pie pastry you want it stretchy
so how do you know when you've stretched
your dough enough when it's mostly
translucent
all the way in the center but the edges
are still a little bit thick here's one
thing I gave up when I first started
making pizza the whole round concept
pizza tastes just as good when it's a
trapezoid so now you've got your dough
exactly where you want it you want to
move it onto a pizza peel if you happen
to have one I use an overturned baking
sheet it works just as well but you want
to flour it up really really well you
don't want your pizza sticking to the
pizza peel and then flopping over onto
the stone that will make a mess I've
done it and then you just move it what
you do is move it around to make sure
it's not sticking anywhere that's all
this is the important thing when you're
making pizza at home you don't want to
overdo it you don't want to pile on the
sauce and pile on the cheese what you
want is to have a light hand you want
the pizza to puff up in the oven and if
it's weighted down with too much stuff
it's not going to puff you're going to
be eating melted cheese on cardboard so
don't do it here's something that I just
learned most pizzerias don't use pasta
sauce for their pizzas it's not a cooked
marinara that they're putting on top
it's a fresh sauce where they take
Tomatoes they put it in the food
processor and I just scatter a little
bit on top you could do it that way
personally I like to use real Tomatoes
and just scatter a few on and what
happens is they get roasted and
condensed in the oven and you get these
intense bites of tomato flavor instead
of the sauce all over but you can do it
either way then you've got to have
garlic you can't have pizza without
garlic it's against the law actually in
New York State olives yes no maybe I
like them if you don't like them don't
use them chili flakes love the chili
flakes are you an anchovy fan I'm an
anchovy fan what you want to do though
use good anchovies mozzarella you can
use pre graded you can buy it and slice
it yourself you can buy fresh mozzarella
whatever you like
the important thing is use a light hand
and then if you want that extra
cheesiness but you don't want the
heaviness of mozzarella here's a trick
this is a good one a little bit of
ricotta ricotta adds a sweet milky
flavor but it doesn't have that
stretchiness of the mozzarella so it's
much lighter and then just kind of
crumble it on to the top of the dough
and it's going to brown and get
pretty and finally a little bit of
Parmesan for Tang you could also use
pecorino okay so now we're all ready to
put this in the oven you're thinking
wait you forgot the basil you forgot the
olive oil I did this on purpose the fact
is the basil is better when you put it
on after the pizza comes out of the oven
otherwise it burns and turns black and I
wait to put the olive oil on until the
pizza is already on the pizza stone
because otherwise it'll encourage it to
stick now into the oven it goes and this
is a scary part but you can do it what's
important here is to position this tray
at the back of the pizza stone otherwise
if you do in the middle the pizza is
going to fall off a little bit of olive
oil just drizzle it on we're gonna bake
it for three minutes and then I'm going
to turn the broiler on and set it for
another three minutes be sure to check
the pizza every minute when it looks
brown and bubbling it's done three
minutes up and now turn the oven off
turn the broiler on the timing on the
pizza is crucial you do not want to get
distracted and walk away don't turn on
the television set don't start answering
emails and for goodness sakes do not
answer the phone
sorry pizzas in the oven Chloe back
should I keep checking it looking good
right Pizza time what I'm doing is I'm
moving it using tongs to move it on to
this tray just as a conveyance to my
cutting board so a nice oval shape not
exactly round but still very attractive
now take a look at the back you can see
that it's nice and crispy and the reason
for that is the pizza stone the heat
rising up from it is what cooks the
bottom of the pizza while the broiler
cooks the top this pizza only feeds
about one so as soon as this comes out
make sure you have your second pie all
ready to go in the oven slip it in you
and your friend can share this and by
the time you're done with this the next
one's ready to go last little touch put
your basil leaves on you could use
rosemary leaves you know if it's not
fresh herbs season you could take some
dried oregano and sprinkle it on the
pizza before it goes in the oven that's
good too tada
looks pretty good right now how to cut
the
thing if you have one of those fancy
wheels go ahead and use it you could use
a serrated bread knife I like my kitchen
shears just cut it up into bite-size
pieces if you want to make traditional
wedges that's fine I say any shape as
long as it fits in your mouth is good
now the second it's cut up serve and eat
it right away the last thing you want to
do with your homemade pizza is to put it
in a cardboard box and send it over to
your neighbor
